STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 13, 2022
JILL SCHREUDER
Catholic Charities West Michigan - Benton Harbor
185 E. Main Street St.102
Benton Harbor, MI 49022
RE: License #: CB110403982
Catholic Charities West Michigan - Benton Harbor
185 E. Main Street St.102
Benton Harbor, MI 49022
Dear Ms. SCHREUDER:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
9/6-9/9/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT

License #: CB110403982
Licensee Name: Catholic Charities West Michigan
Licensee Address: Suite 3A
360 South Division
Grand Rapids, MI 49503
Licensee Telephone #: (616) 243-9122

Name of Facility: Catholic Charities West Michigan - Benton
Harbor
Facility Address: 185 E. Main Street St.102
Benton Harbor, MI 49022
Facility Telephone #: (269) 593-1000

CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE

EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
2 of 9 employee files reviewed contained performance evaluations that were not
completed timely. One was a 6-month evaluation and the other an annual
evaluation.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to accept
the foster child.
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received orientation
to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
1 of 3 borrowed bed files reviewed contained documentation that the foster parent
was provided and signed the documents required per subsections b, f, & g - 1 day
after the youth was placed in their home.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at
minimum, include all of the following:
(f)The provision of a dental examination and any
treatment required for each child who is 4 years of age
and older, including the following:
(ii)A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least every
18 months unless greater frequency is required.
1 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed contained documentation that a youth's
periodic dental exam was not completed timely.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth
and the social service worker. The contract shall be
4

reviewed and updated at least once every 90 calendar
days and a copy provided to the youth.
1 of 2 open files of youth living independently did not contain any IL contracts.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 11/2/21, CAP Approval 11/16/21
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing
an adoption application and prior to approving a family for
adoption.
2 of 3 adoption family assessments reviewed were not completed timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 11/2/21, CAP Approval 11/16/21
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least
once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
1 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed contained 1 USP that was completed 1
day late.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP)
- within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
5

Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business days
prior to a planned change of placement or no later than three
business days after an unplanned placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case closure
date or one business day after unplanned court ordered
dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is
used to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety concerns and
the safety plan, and any recommendations made for the family
during the FTM. The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business days of the FTM.
5 of 8 open case files reviewed (6 FC & 2 IL) did not contain documentation that the
required service plan development FTMs were held. Additionally, 1 of the 5 cases
did not contain all required 1105's for FTMs documented to have been held.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 11/2/21, CAP Approval 11/16/21
FOM 722-06J RIGHTS OF CHILDREN IN FOSTER CARE
Within 30 calendar days of removal, the caseworker must review
and explain the DHS-5307, Rights and Responsibilities for
Children and Youth in Foster Care, and the agency's grievance
policy with the child, foster parents, caregivers, and parents. The
caseworker must be prepared to answer any questions the child,
parents, and caregivers may have.
After the document is reviewed the signatures of the child and
caseworker must be obtained. The parent or caregiver must sign
on behalf of the child, if the child is younger than 11 years old or is
unable to sign the document. The caseworker must complete the
information on the last page of the document with the applicable
contact information and provide all participants with a signed copy
and upload a copy to MiSACWIS.
Placement Change When a child under age 11 or who is
otherwise unable to sign the DHS-5307 changes placement, the
caseworker must review the DHS-5307 and the agency's
grievance policy with the new caregiver and obtain their
signature on the DHS-5307 within 30 days of the placement
change.
6

Documentation The DHS-5307 must be reviewed and re-
signed annually. The caseworker must document the review in
the social work contacts, and the caseworker must upload the
DHS-5307 to the Documents hyperlink in MiSACWIS.
3 of 10 total foster care case files reviewed (6 open FC, 2 closed FC, and 2 open IL)
did not contain all required 5307 signatures and/or documentation that the form was
provided and explained.
FOM 722-07F PERMANENCY PLANNING - PPFWR AND APPLA
The DHS-643, Permanency Goal Review, is the change form for
all changes and reviews of permanency goals. For PPFWR and
APPLA, within 30 calendar days of a change in the relative
placement or the supportive adult, and within 30 calendar days
of the annual review date, the DHS-643, Permanency Goal
Review, must be completed and submitted to the permanency
resource monitor for review. Note: Additional permanency plan
approval packet documentation may be required depending on
the reason for review. Annual Review Date The annual review
date is calculated from permanency goal established date; see
Changing the Permanency Goal in this item.
1 of 2 open files of youth living independently did not contain an annually completed
643.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 11/2/21, CAP Approval 11/16/21
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Caseworker
 Supervisor
 Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are placed
apart
 Parents who are a member of a participating household.
 Youth ages 14 and older.
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-
ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must check yes
or no for the following when signing the treatment plan:
 I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
 I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
7

 I have been provided a copy of the Case Service Plan
and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review, and I will
have the opportunity to express my disagreement with
the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the
treatment plan, the caseworker must identify, and document
actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or youth’s
participation in service planning and compliance with the
treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
5 of 8 open case files reviewed (6 FC & 2 IL) did not contain all signatures, obtained
as required, on all PATP's.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as 722-08C
Interim Inspection Report 11/2/21, CAP Approval 11/16/21
Renewal Inspection Report 9/24/20, CAP Approval 10/14/20
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in caseworker or
organization. • Change in parent contact information. • Foster
care transfer to adoption. • Change in placement. • Temporary
break from placement. • Program or case closing.
COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change.
Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure -
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
Caseworker/ Organization Change - Within three business
days of change in caseworker and/or organization.
8

3 of 10 total foster care case files reviewed (6 open FC, 2 closed FC, and 2 open IL)
did not contain all required action summaries completed within the required
timeframes. 2 of the 3 were closed files for which the action summaries can no
longer be uploaded and 1 was for an agency/placement change.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as 722-09C
Interim Inspection Report 11/2/21, CAP Approval 11/16/21
Renewal Inspection Report 9/24/20, CAP Approval 10/14/20
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Two case contacts documenting foster home visits reviewed were blank and
appeared to have been used as placeholders. These had been entered for longer
than the required 5 days with no narrative. Entering placeholders in order to meet
entry timeframes does not meet the requirement.
 Social worker contacts regarding foster home visits must contain documentation
of all required discussions outlined in policy.
 Several of the PATP's reviewed had the handwritten "mailed" on signature lines
but were not dated and no social work contacts were located documenting when
the documents were mailed. Additionally, the majority of the mailed PATP's were
to case members who were actively participating and with whom regular face to
face contacts were being made. Documents must only be mailed as an exception
when circumstances prevent obtaining physical signatures. The documents
requiring signatures (parent/caregiver/youth) must be explained to the signing
party. It appears that the majority of missing signature documents were mailed a
week prior to the inspection and, in several cases, the individuals to whom the
documents were mailed were actively participating in the case and with whom
regular face to face contacts were being made.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Foster Home Visit case contacts do not have all participants linked. The
participants must be linked to the contact to accurately identify who was present.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The one CAP submitted by the agency was in response to the 11/2/2021 interim
licensing inspection report and was approved on 11/16/2021. That CAP addressed
9

15 violations and was successful in achieving compliance in 9 of the 15 areas. Six
violations addressed in that CAP were repeated violations during this inspection and
will required additional corrective action planning.
Chief Administrator Assessment – The chief administrator assessment was
received prior to the inspection and discussed during the entrance meeting. The chief
administrator accurately identified areas that needed improvement and discussed
plans the agency has already identified in order to improve compliance.
Interviews – The staff members interviewed all reported no concerns other than
being fairly new to their roles and still learning all of the requirements.
VII. DCWL Analyst Concerns
No safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
September 9, 2022
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 12, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
10
